description: From Middle English schip-wracke, from Old English sċipwræc (“jetsam”), equivalent to ship +‎ wrack. Cognate with Scots schip-wrak (“to shipwreck”, verb), Swedish skeppsvrak (“shipwreck”). Modern form is due to influence from wreck.

entries.meaning: A ship that has sunk or run aground so that it is no longer seaworthy.
examples: heaven will drive shipwrecks ashore to make us all rich

entries.meaning: (countable, uncountable) An event where a ship sinks or runs aground.
examples: they made the coast of Cochin China, and the tempests, which rose at the same time, threatened them more than once with shipwreck
Holding faith and a good conscience, which some having put away concerning faith have made shipwreck.

verbs.description: shipwreck (third-person singular simple present shipwrecks, present participle shipwrecking, simple past and past participle shipwrecked)

entries.meaning: To wreck a boat through a collision or mishap.
